titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Brooks Family Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Scott Libson and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:04

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The Brooks Family Papers contain materials relating to Harold Allen Brooks, Sr., Mildred McNeill-Brooks, and their son, Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. The materials consist of correspondence, writings, financial documents, photographs, and research files. The latter contains materials regarding Frank Lloyd Wright, other Prairie School architects, and Charles-Edouard Jeanneret. The research files on Jeanneret bring together documents and photographs collected from around the world and provide comprehensive documentation of Jeanneret's personal life, influences, and architectural career. There is a presentation drawing by Euston made after the architect's first visit to the site in the spring of 1939 and a writing by H. Allen Brooks as to why he became an architectural historian as it relates to the presentation drawing.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Material from Accession 2011-M-007 was interfiled into Series III, box 15 of original accession.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of H. Allen Brooks, 2000, 2004, 2006, and 2010.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Additional information is provided in the finding aid.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Brooks Family Papers (MS 1784). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Woodruff Family Papers, MS 1143. Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in four series and two additions: I. Mildred McNeill-Brooks, 1866-1990. II. Harold Allen Brooks, Sr., 1893-1950. III. Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. Personal, Correspondence, and Writings, 1925-2002. IV. Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. Research, 1899-2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold Allen Brooks, Sr. was born in New Haven, Connecticut, in 1886. He served in the army during World War I and afterwards became a banker. In June 1923, he married Mildred McNeill. McNeill was born in Brooklyn, New York, in 1895. She attended Vassar College and was a nurse with the YWCA before marrying Brooks. Both died in the early 1950s.

Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. was born in 1925. Brooks, Jr., received degrees from Dartmouth College (B.A., 1950), Yale University (M.A., 1955), and Northwestern University (Ph.D., 1957). He served in the United States Army. For most of his professional career, Brooks, Jr. taught architectural history at the University of Toronto. He specialized in Frank Lloyd Wright and the Prairie School and Charles-Edouard Jeanneret, commonly known as Le Corbusier. Brooks, Jr. publications include The Prairie School: Frank Lloyd Wright and his Midwest Contemporaries and Le Corbusier's Formative Years. He also edited the thirty-two volume Le Corbusier Archive and served as president of the Society of Architectural Historians. In 1986, Brooks, Jr. became professor emeritus of architecture at the University of Toronto. He died on August 8, 2010, in Hanover, New Hampshire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brooks Family Papers contain materials relating to Harold Allen Brooks, Sr., Mildred McNeill-Brooks, and their son, Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. The materials consist of correspondence, writings, financial documents, photographs, and research files. The latter contains materials regarding Frank Lloyd Wright, other Prairie School architects, and Charles-Edouard Jeanneret. The research files on Jeanneret bring together documents and photographs collected from around the world and provide comprehensive documentation of Jeanneret's personal life, influences, and architectural career. There is a presentation drawing by Euston made after the architect's first visit to the site in the spring of 1939 and a writing by H. Allen Brooks as to why he became an architectural historian as it relates to the presentation drawing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains personal papers of Mildred McNeill-Brooks. Correspondence has been left in original envelopes and is arranged chronologically. Diaries, also arranged chronologically, document the daily life of McNeill-Brooks from the age of 14 until her death in 1951. Subjects discussed include travel abroad, foreign cultures, social events with friends, married life, and on occasion, national and international events. The Albums, Scrapbook, and Yearbooks provide photographic material and personal information about McNeill-Brooks and her ancestors. Many of the Photographs are identified and some include dates. Drawings of Connecticut landscapes are often signed by McNeill-Brooks

did.unittitle: "National League for Women's Service Automobile Section" certificate
World War I YWCA nursing certificate

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series mostly consist of financial documents including bank statements, checks, receipts, and stock certificates. There is a limited amount of personal materials and correspondence. One folder documents Brooks's service in World War I. A large album of unidentified photographs, probably from the mid-nineteenth century, is included in the series, as well as an additional folder of photographs.

did.unittitle: Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. Personal, Correspondence, and Writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is comprised of non-research materials of Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. Personal papers are arranged topically and contain biographical information. The majority consist of photographs and slides that have been left in their original containers with Brooks's identification. The photographs document Brooks's personal life from childhood through retirement. Correspondence is subdivided into personal and professional correspondence, following Brooks's own arrangement. Professional correspondence is primarily arranged chronologically, but includes topically arranged files. Personal correspondence is arranged chronologically and is mainly dated to the 1940s and after 1980. The former has been left in original envelopes and is largely outgoing correspondence to Brooks's parents. Short Writings and Books files comprise the majority of the Writings section. Short Writings include handwritten and typed manuscripts. It is unclear whether they were published.

did.unittitle: Loose [mostly positives, includes some slides; one folder of negatives, box 17; one folder of drawings, box 18]
"Join the Army and See the World"
Arts and Humanities Foundation [includes administrative records]
Massachusetts Institute of Technology Press [includes administrative records]
Society of Architectural Historians [includes administrative records; 9 folders]
Journal of cross-country trip [in form of a series of letters to his parents]
Graduate school papers [includes photographs and notes relating to Yale masters thesis on Leonard Eidlitz; 2 folders]

Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

did.unittitle: "F. L. W.: The Destruction of the Box"
Reproductions used in the book [4 folders]
Frank Lloyd Wright and the Prairie School [by Brooks]
Prairie School Architecture [edited and introduced by Brooks; 2 copies]
The Prairie School: Frank Lloyd Wright and His Midwest Contemporaries [by Brooks]
Writings on Wright [edited, introduced, and with commentary by Brooks]
Reviews of H. Allen Brooks, Jr.'s books [2 folders]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The research files of Harold Allen Brooks, Jr. consist of notes, correspondence, printed materials, photographs, and photocopies of original documents. The series is divided into two sections: Prairie School/Frank Lloyd Wright and Charles-Edouard Jeanneret (Le Corbusier).

The Prairie School materials are arranged topically with folder headings derived largely from Brooks's own titles. A large number of photographs, mostly identified and mainly used in Brooks's book, The Prairie School: Frank Lloyd Wright and his Midwest Contemporaries , are a substantial part of the series. Prairie School also contains drawings and blueprints of the buildings of Prairie School architects.

The arrangement of the research files on Jeanneret corresponds to Brooks'sbook, Le Corbusier's Formative Years . Wherever possible, the integrity of Brooks's ordering and folder titles has been maintained. A large amount of the Jeanneret material consists of photocopies of original handwritten correspondence, writings, and drawings, collected from around the world. Much of this material was later transcribed and where transcriptions exist, they follow the photocopied originals. Near the end of the series are audiotapes of interviews conducted by Brooks and others with individuals who knew Jeanneret.

did.unittitle: General [includes miscellaneous photographs and plans; 11 folders]
"Walter Burley Griffin in His Own Right"

did.unittitle: Black-line prints of Jeanneret buildings and drawings
Notecard files [handwritten; alphabetically arranged by topic]
List of H. Allen Brooks's publications

Short writings by H. Allen Brooks regarding Charles-Edouard Jeanneret (Le Corbusier) and the Prairie School architects [articles, book reviews, and reviews of Brooks's books; includes printed materials, reprints, clippings, and drafts]
Ph.D. dissertation, "The Prairie School, The American Spirit in Midwest Residential Architecture, 1893-1916"
Presentation drawing by Andrew Euston of the Brooks residence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This presentation drawing by Euston was made after the architect's first visit to the site in the spring of 1939, the house being designed and built almost exactly as shown. Included is a writing by H. Allen Brooks as to why he became an architectural historian as it relates to this drawing.
